pullRequest.body:
Add the definition of pushdown automata and their two acceptance conditions: acceptance based on empty stack and acceptance based on final state.

Co-authored-by: Tobias Leichtfried <tobias.leichtfried@tuwien.ac.at>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [367dcccc26](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22159/commits/367dcccc26697457fe74c1a25f64cfeaa19fb94d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Computability.PDA` (new file)|546|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Conf`
`+ PDA`
`+ Reaches`
`+ Reaches‚ÇÅ`
`+ acceptsByEmptyStack`
`+ acceptsByFinalState`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks for the PR! Here are mostly style comments

You are adding a bunch of definitions with no API. I understand this is the first PR of many, but from the point of view of mathlib it is no good acquiring definitions if we can't prove anything about them.

Could you therefore add some simple lemmas about the new definitions, eg `_ \in acceptsByEmptyStack _ \iff _`?

If the PR becomes too long as a result, please remove some definitions: It's better to PR definition A and lemmas about A, then definition B and lemmas about B, rather than definitions A and B, then lemmas about A and B.

Thank you!

```suggestion
/-- A PDA is a set of states (`Q`), a tape alphabet (`T`), a stack alphabet (`S`), an initial state
```

```suggestion
  finite (q : Q) (a : T) (Z : S) : (transition_fun q a Z).Finite
```

```suggestion
  finite' (q : Q) (Z : S) : (transition_fun' q Z).Finite
```
I'd rather treat the automaton as data, hence single-letter name.
Do I understand you correctly that you suggest to rename `pda` to, e.g., `M`? Is there some mathlib naming convention I am not aware of?
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html
I'm not sure if both definitions `step` and `Reaches‚ÇÅ` should exist.

Me neither. From my point of view it would seem simpler, to just define `Reaches‚ÇÅ` as a disjunction. This would also get rid of the set notation of step. @TobiasLeichtfried: do you have an opinion on that?
I have now added a more compact definition of Reaches‚ÇÅ that does not use step.
If we had a `++` that prepends an `(Option T)` to a `(List T)` we could even get rid of the disjunction by quantifying directly over `(x : Option T)`. I am not sure if this is preferable though...
Could a better name be possible? Like `transition_skip` or `transition_stay` or something.
Another option may be to use an `Option T`. This is the way epsilon transitions are dealt with in NFAs.

```suggestion
  /-- Transition function reading a letter from `T`. -/
```
Could it be written as `{ ‚ü®p, w, (Œ≤ ++ Œ±)‚ü© | something }` and similar below?
This may not even be necessary, depending on how we deal with `Reaches‚ÇÅ`.
This is not necessary anymore, since the definition of step has been removed.

```suggestion
  { w : List T | ‚àÉ q ‚àà pda.final_states, ‚àÉ Œ≥ : List S,
```

You shouldn't indent here
```suggestion
(`initial_state`), a start symbol (`start_symbol`), a set of final states (`final_states`), a
transition function (`transition_fun`), and a proof that, for any input, the transition function
returns a finite set as output. -/
```
Same below

```suggestion
  initialState : Q
```

```suggestion
  startSymbol : S
```
Why is it "*initial* state", but "*start* symbol"?

This is the terminology in one of the classics on the subject, the book our formalisation is based on: _Hopcroft, Ullman: Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation, Addison-Wesley, 1979._ I am not sure about the root of this distinction.
That is strange. Could you record this strangeness by adding a sentence in each of the two docstrings?

```suggestion
  finalStates : Set Q
```

```suggestion
  transitionFun : Q ‚Üí Option T ‚Üí S ‚Üí Set (Q √ó List S)
```

```suggestion
  finite_transitionFun (q : Q) (x : Option T) (Z : S) : (transitionFun q x Z).Finite
```

Have you considering bundling those two fields into
```suggestion
  /-- Transition function reading a letter from `T` if present and an epsilon otherwise. -/
  transition_fun : Q ‚Üí (Option T) ‚Üí S ‚Üí Finset (Q √ó List S)
```

My student @TobiasLeichtfried has done this formalisation. IIRC he thought about using Finset but it turned out that using .Finite was considerably simpler. I am not sure what would be preferred in this context.

> he thought about using Finset but it turned out that using .Finite was considerably simpler. I am not sure what would be preferred in

It would be good to know exactly what was painful with finsets. Finsets are possibly not easy to work with originally, but their use pays off.

You've got too many brackets
```suggestion
    r‚ÇÅ.input = r‚ÇÇ.input ‚àß (r‚ÇÇ.state, Œ≤) ‚àà M.transition_fun r‚ÇÅ.state none Z ‚à®
    ‚àÉ (a : T), r‚ÇÅ.input = a :: r‚ÇÇ.input ‚àß (r‚ÇÇ.state, Œ≤) ‚àà (M.transition_fun r‚ÇÅ.state (some a) Z)
```

```suggestion
  ‚àÉ (Z : S) (Œ± : List S) (Œ≤ : List S), r‚ÇÅ.stack = Z :: Œ± ‚àß r‚ÇÇ.stack = Œ≤ ++ Œ± ‚àß (
```

```suggestion
    ‚àÉ a : T, r‚ÇÅ.input = a :: r‚ÇÇ.input ‚àß (r‚ÇÇ.state, Œ≤) ‚àà M.transitionFun r‚ÇÅ.state (some a) Z
```

```suggestion
condition. -/
```
Same above

pullRequest.title: feat: add definition of pushdown automata
